reviewText:
From Sonic, Sonic 2 and Sonic3&Knuckles comes the sequel we have all waited for: Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode I, where the franchise goes back to its roots to try and redeliver the classic momentum based platformer that carried Sega to success in 1991.

Unfortunately the game does not deserve the complement of its predecessors as for the most part the game insults the classic era of the franchise with a mediocre game that has a inferiority complex - trash can't disguise itself amongst gold.

The level design does not complement the momentum and even the momentum mechanics of the game are poor or rather broken and don't hold their own to the older brothers which will leave you with nothing but a sigh as the game spoonfeeds you dash panels so that you don't earn your speed and you're not punished for mistakes.

The developers don't understand that earning your momentum gives you a fresh experience when you replay the level and you understand the layout well enough not to crash into Badniks or spikes which is why the ring system is there in the first place; so you can fail multiple times, learn from your mistakes instead of punishing you downright so once you finally learn you're allowed to hold the reins of speed and all its goodness.

Taking that away devalues what made the classic games in the first place. The game also introduces the homing attack that is forced on you and drops every bit of speed you've gained so far.

Despite what has been said about the level design, Zone 4 takes a few steps towards the right direction but it doesn't stop the game from falling on its face, you also have the terrible floaty physics and the poor (re-)designed bosses to also thank for that.

The music however is great and with the beautiful visuals are very reminiscent of the classic Sonic games are by far the strongest points of this product which thankfully don't collapse with the disappointment of the game. Even the 2.5D models are great other than Sonic's model itself oddly enough.

What makes this game bearable is the fact that it's a average platformer game when you don't compare it to its far superior prequels, the length is very great for its price and the online time attack where you can compete against other players that can have you playing for hours to see who can break and exploit the game to the finish line the fastest.

The game is by all means worth the £6 but you're better off spending a bit more of that money to buy games like DuckTales Remastered and/or Sonic 4 Episode 2, despite them having lower scores on gaming review sites they're superior in everyway.

What did you like best about Sonic 2? Was it the original, varied and yet level design? The clever bosses that never repeated an idea? The game design which is involved and challenging, but still only uses one button? Well, you better go play Sonic 2 and 3 then, because this steaming pile of refuse does the exact opposite of everything I mentioned.

The Sonic sprite is rendered with a shader﻿ to have only the three tones of blue in his Sonic 3 sprites that clashes with everything else in the game including other images of Sonic which are shown with normal shaders.

The art design is recycled from previous games wholesale with tweaks to upscale it believably to modern resolutions. And I don't mean like Sonic 2's Emerald Hill Zone compared to Green Hill Zone, Splash Hill Zone straight up lifted the tileset from Emerald Hill and there isn't a single new enemy desgin until you get to the third zone.

The boss designs are also copied shamelessly from the Megadrive games. I will grant Sega that there is purpose in revisiting the classic Ball and Chain Robotnik from Green Hill Zone Act 3 as it is one of the most iconic bosses from that era of gaming. I vocally sighed when I saw the boss of Casino Street Zone (just what you think it is, with a twinge of Carnival Night) was the Neon Claw Robotnik from Casino Night Act 2.

If that's not bad enough, they completely missed the point of the bosses as well. Oldschool Sonic bosses were great in how they were a quiz of the mechanics taught in the zone. With Ball and Chain, you had to have paitence and basic use of the platform to reach Robotnik and avoid damage. Claw forced you to use the spin dash to go up the walls to avoid him grabbing you and sucking out your rings. Both of the aforementioned things can be completely ignored with the basic application of the homing attack, begging their inclusion at all. They do go into a different and new attack pattern after 5 hits, but why not do something FULLY original if that's your goal?

The addition of the homing attack adds nothing to the game other than removing any semblance of game design based challenge based upon platforming. There is still plenty of hard work to do though; fighting the incredibly buggy, awful physics (it is possible to *walk* around a loop with no momentum) and puzzles.

Yes, I said puzzles. Someone that developed this idea thought that placing a puzzle that completely forced you to a stop until you light up a specific set of torches that lowers a wall to allow you to continue in a franchise where speed and flow are *paramount* was a good idea.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ANY REASON. The fact that it was ever considered shippable is insulting. If you want a good modern Sonic game, vote with your wallet for Generations.

reviewText:
I went into Sonic 4 episode 1 expecting to hate it. At first I did. I saw all the nostalgia they're trying to recreate the feeling old Sonic levels with new technology and graphics. It felt like there was nothing new. The more I played, the more it felt like there was a freshness to the old 2D platforming of Sonic. For those who have never played the old Sonic games, they are labyrinth levels that you need to make it to the end. Along the way you collect rings. These rings let you take damage without dying. The rings go spraying everywhere when you get hit. If you have no rings, you will die when you get hit. The game is single player only and offers controller or keyboard support that you setup out of game.

It feels the same as the original games and not much has changed control wise. There is still one button controls. The one button will make you jump while you're standing or running. If you hold down and push the jump button you will perform a spin dash when you let go of the down. When you are running, you can press down to roll into a ball to kill enemies. New to the series is what I feel is a game changer. A mid air lock on dash. Just hit the jump button in mid air and Sonic will immediately dart to whatever he has targeted. Usually the closest enemy, spring board or item box. This is a game changer because it adds constant momentum that is easy and more efficient than a spin dash that takes a second or so. Just jump and dart in mid air. Its easy and efficient. Not just that, but attacking enemies in the air turns into platforming. It feels like a lot less time wasted gaining momentum. With this new mechanic, I can see why Tails wasn't included in this first episode.

The game looks great. It has detailed backgrounds and bright vibrant colors. There are four main areas, each with three levels and a boss fight. Each area has a theme from a previous Sonic game. There is no new territory. Consider it a best of rather than a new album. With that said, Sonic 4 takes them in interesting new directions every so often unique to Sonic 4. One level features a lot of cannons that Sonic can hop in and control where he shoots out. Another level has Sonic in a mine cart and keeping his balance on rolling boulders. You'll see Sonic in the dark carrying a torch, lighting things on the wall to open doors and activate platforms. It all feels fresh, even if it steps away from the Genesis. There are still classic Sonic tropes like using pinball flippers, bouncing off bumpers, going through loops, swinging from vines, using zip lines (Sonic Advance) and so on.  There are a few moments of going underwater. While underwater, Sonic just moves slower. He can't actually swim.

The items feel limited to the ones found in Sonic 1 and 2. You can get temporary invincibility, ten rings, an extra life, super speed shoes and a bubble shield that lets Sonic take an extra hit.

Even with only 4 areas to visit, there are still 13 levels (not including boss fights). Each level is around five minutes to complete. I hate to say it, but it feels like a full length Sonic game, even if this is only episode 1. It runs around the three hour mark. The boss fights evoke nostalgia. Their patterns are like the original games, but they add new twists.

Sonic 4 does a good job of utilizing Sonic's speed. A lot of the previous 2D games had you go at your own pace, but Sonic 4 has you chased by boulders, crushing walls, running after Dr. Robotnik in boss fights. These reasons for Sonic to run feel engaging more than typical exploring the levels. It offers a variety.

Since you are collecting rings, if you complete the level and have more than 50 rings, you'll see a giant ring to jump into that sends you to the bonus stage. Even the bonus stage feels good. Its a take off of the original Sonic 1 bonus stage, but this time you get to control the rotation of the level while Sonic is just stuck in a ball. There are barriers that need coins to pass through. At the end of each bonus stage is a chaos emerald.

As you progress, you will unlock levels and areas as you progress. So if you get stuck on a level, you can skip it. After each level it gives you a choice to jump to the next unfinished level. That just feels odd. While its helpful to have level selection, I'd much rather progress to the next level instead of getting asked.

While this might be a departure from the old Sonic games, it adds new life to what was a stale franchise if you include the Genesis and Gameboy Advance platformers. The challenge feels good, its more difficult than the other old school games.

reviewText:
This game does exactly what it set out to do, and nothing more. To satiate the thirst fans of the franchise crying out for a return to the original trilogy. What is still considered to be one of the best games to date by many. But the mark is missed by a want to set the game apart.

The visuals are adequate and pleasing, but are not remarkable or noteworthy. It looks like a derivative cash in on Sonic The Hedgehog 2's success, yet manages to be less inspiring. While vibrant and varied, it still somehow manages to feel soulless. On top of that, the characters themselves seem to have a cell shaded sheen to them that clashes with the rest of the game and ends up looking awkward.

Controls are different from the original games this title was meant to bank on. In order to keep momentum, one must hold in the direction you intend to run in. The spin dash does not gain traction and ends up being the worse option to gain speed in the long run. It's only useful for a short burst if you're looking not to get hit by enemies (which, by the way, seem to be quite scarce and poorly placed). Otherwise the homing attack happens to be your best choice for a speed boost. The stages themselves, though, did feel decently designed and were loyal to the original Genesis games. I, myself, ended up finding more enjoyment in the special stages, though.

For the audio, much of sound effects, and it almost felt like the soundboard itself, was lifted from Sonic The Hedgehog 2. This would have been awesome if the music wasn't so forgettable. Nothing truly outstanding, unlike the game from which inspired all its audio.

True, I have been quite negative, but don't take that as a reason not to play this game. It's still a decent experience worth giving a try. Once you get past the different controls, you can enjoy the game much like you would in the original Genesis titles. If you go into this knowing it's not those games, but instead and game on its own inspired but not completely copied, you can find enjoyment in playing it.

As a day one Sonic fan who played the original Genesis titles as soon as they came out. This is a really good Sonic game. The game took old concepts for levels and created something fresh and new. With platforming puzzles that would use old mechanics in a brand new and interesting way.

After 10-15 years of bare bones, turn your brain off Sonic gameplay. I feel the audience for Sonic just didn't want a game like this. Episode 1 will actually challenge you a little bit. You'll find platforming puzzles, because Sonic is a platformer. A shocker to some, I know. I feel that's the main reason why people preferred Episode2 over Ep1. Ep2 looks gorgeous and is completely brain dead.

Also it's worth noting, the nitpicks about the physics and earning speed are misguided. The physics are 90% the same and there's no meaningful difference between this and the classics. Earning speed is also a talking point parroted by people who didn't want to take the time to figure out what was really bothering them. For example, who complained the spindash in Sonic 2 took the 'earning speed' element out of the game? The real reason why it didn't feel like a Genesis Sonic game was the save system:

This game was designed to be played through once without having to replay levels. There's no muscle memory or memorization of level layouts, unlike there was in Sonic 1-2.

Fantastic addition to the good old side scrolling Sonic the Hedgehog series.

Graphics are more or less the same on all platforms. Unfortunately the game has a fixed internal resolution of 720p and no AA so all the 3D models have jaggies galore. I managed to get some AA going with an injector (Radeon Pro), I think it may be possible to force AA in windowed mode as well.

Sound is pretty standard Sonic fare, everything you would expect for a Sonic game

Gameplay is essentially unchanged from the original games aside from some extra spin dash moves. Plays pretty much the same as the old games and I would rate the difficulty as pretty similar, which means that it is quite challenging. The game  takes much longer than the older games to finish, it took me a few afternoons whereas the older titles could be completed in less than an hour.

A well put together game, worth the modest price and the next episode ticks all the same boxes.

reviewText:
Yeah, no.  Sorry.  The princess is in another castle.  Bahahaha VIDEO GAME JOKEZ.

Man, I really wanted to like this game because, yeah, I like Sonic.  He's really only worked in 2d, though (I didn't care for Sonic Adventures, personally).  When I saw this a few years ago I was like oh man, exciting!  A new, potentially good sonic game!  And then all of the disappointment.

The two biggest factors as to why I don't recommend this game: the engine and the level design.  Graphics are a close third.

The engine is just kind of meh.  Sonic feels very bulky, heavy and slow in this game.  More than once I've stood on a hill and, after losing momentum, could not actually finish climbing said hill.  I had to go back, get a running start and then run up.  It didn't feel very sonic like and it very much breaks pacing/immersion/fun.

However, the level design is what kept me from wanting to finish.  It's just kind of meh overall, like a  bland cut/copy/paste of what a marketing person thinks a sonic game should look like, having looked at the statistics and level design of previous games.  It feels very soulless, much like the New Super Mario brothers series.  Sure, it looks similar to the original Sonic games but it lacks it's own character or creativity.  You can usually safely call where a spike trap will be, for example, because  the placements are so obvious.  That's not bad, necessarily -- you should be able to tell where the pitfalls are going to come up -- but they're predictable in the way that makes the game boring.

What really broke my spirits, though, was the third level: the ♥♥♥♥ing water level.  Water levels always kind of suck in Sonic, but in the past I at least appreciated their unique-ness as they did some cool things.  This one doesn't.  One stage has a massive pain in the ♥♥♥ puzzle where you light specific torches at specific times in order to make platforms rise and fall, but the torches burn out so quickly that Sonic's slow, impercise ♥♥♥ can't easily get onto these ledges before they disappear.  I personally was stuck on one part of a stage for a good 5-10 minutes just trying to get Sonic to do what I wanted him to do.  That's not a good game.  Worse still is the boss fight for that stage, which is a race to catch and damage Robotnik.  Except, you know, the race involves very specific jumps while water is rising.  Of course the water slows you down, and at that point why even bother?

No, I had a pretty bad time with this game and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone unless you really wanted to see how to ♥♥♥♥ up a 2d sonic game.  It just doesn't do much right.  Even Sonic Colors -- a game I also do not like -- was designed better than this.  I really want to like it, but it's just not very good.  If you want a good Sonic game, go check out Sonic Generations instead.

This is literally one of the worst Sonic games I've ever played, probably worse than Sonic 06 only because that game is so bad it's good, had hilarious glitches and it has a nice soundtrack unlike this... thing. Where to start?

MUSIC:

The music is awful and uses really bad instruments and boring melodies. There's only 2 or 3 good tracks in the entire game and even then they're all only a handfull of seconds long, which means you'll listen to the very same loop over and over and over and over.

You would think that's fine because it's a Sonic game after all, you're supposed to finish stages fast. Well? How about the last stage which is a boss rush that can last 8 minutes with ease? And it has two different songs, both terrible and 15 seconds long if not less.

A bit of trivia about the songs. The standard boss song at the beginning of a boss stage is actually an unused song from Sonic 3D blast. GRAPHICS:

Can't complain and don't give 2 hedgehogs about what people say about how sonic looks like. Could be worse, he could be Sonic Adventure DX glossy but he's not. Not like that saves this game from being utter crap.

Boring start -> random hills -> chain of enemy appears! -> homing attack a few times -> BOOSTER -> BOOSTER -> jump

reviewText:
I don't know what this is, but it is not a Sonic game.  While it may look like a Sonic game, and sound a bit like a Sonic game, it fundamentally lacks the core components that made the original Genesis-era Sonic games so good: tight, responsive controls, and blazing fast speed.  Sonic 4 lacks both.

Controlling Sonic feels sluggish and muted, like he's stuck in molasses.  That's an apt description for the game's speed, too, because even at Sonic's utter fastest you feel like you're barely poking along, the blurring legs of his full-out sprint matching in no way the pathetically slow rate at which the scenery moves.  Not only that, but Sonic retains almost no momentum, slowing down rapidly the moment you take your fingers from the controls.  At first I thought this had all been done to make it easier to see upcoming hazards - a problem in earlier Sonic titles - but the game's zoomed in, over-large view of its new scaled-up art means you get an even smaller view of the world around you than in previous titles, not more.  It makes the whole thing feel claustrophobic, slow, and frankly un-Sonic-like.

I can't recommend this game.  It's one of the most disappointing Sonic titles I've ever played.

The backgrounds are gorgeous and the feel of the original games has almost been emulated to perfection. The game can be finished in a couple of hours - which, I think, is actually a pretty perfect length for a 2D Sonic game.

It's no Sonic 2, but it's still a sold 2D Sonic game.

Cheap, cheap, cheap deaths and a lazy concept (all the zones are mashups of previous 2D zones) ruin what had the potential to be a great true Sonic sequel. Last impression: The final boss is all the previous bosses in sequence (back to the point about laziness) followed by an altered version of the Sonic 2 final boss.

I've beaten him, twice, but I HAVEN'T beaten him - Robotnik bashes the ground causing it to crumble, and after all you've done, the entire battle comes down to whether you're well-placed and quick enough (within a split second) to hit a certain hit, or die. I failed both times, and I was done.

Episode II is a little better solely for the inclusion of Tails, who can fly you out of cheap deaths and pick up rings for you, counter-acting the awful levels and bosses.

reviewText:
For the record: This isn't a bad game because it's not a true classic sonic game. It's a bad game on its own merits.

Though it certainly is insanely far from a true classic series game. I mean, when every stage in the game is a rehash of a Sonic 1 or 2 zone (and thus entirely unoriginal, something the original series was not) then obviously it's playing off nostalgia fuel. But it doesn't play like those games. It relies on gimmicks instead of level design. Literally every single act barring the first is built around a gimmick. The physics are also all wrong, too; not remotely similar to the classic games, and playing more like the 2D bits of the modern sonic stages in Generations (see the problem there?).

But I wouldn't care if the game was any good by itself. But... it's not. There's an out of nowhere difficulty spike at the second act of the second zone (and only near the end). Which would matter if you didn't already have 50 lives by that point because the game showers you in them, removing any sense of difficulty. Dying becomes annoying and tedious more than anything. Some of the gimmicks, also, are pretty bad. Mad Gear Act 3's, especially. Since a lot of it requires you to learn where to jump since screwing up once = instant death. Yup. Good job with that one.

And let's not get started on the boss design. Well for one every single boss is a carbon copy of a Sonic 1/2 boss, or at least starts out that way. And the newly added bits to the later three are all awful. No, instant-death crusher traps in a sonic boss are not good. No, a sonic advance 2 styled running boss with the occasional impossible to dodge attack is not cool. And no, making Sonic 2's final boss even more tedious and unfair is not cool. Seriously, that thing has broken hitboxes and takes a bloody eternity.

The game doesn't have particularly good presentation, either. A lot of the graphical elements clash, and the music is the first time I've ever found a sonic soundtrack actively bad. It's just... horrible music. Truly terrible.

There's... nothing really to recommend here, at all. I didn't expect a great game but I didn't even get a decent one.

reviewText:
(BTW, if you're wondering why my in game time is short, its because I played the Wii release first, back in 2011-ish)


This game is a disapointment. It promised to bring the franchise back to its roots, but it failed.


I'm not saying this game is horrible, it just doesn't feel like a traditional (classic) Sonic title.


Issues with the game:

- The level designs feel way too linear -

There are way too many large bottomless pits in stages, boostpads that make you go fast, springs that lead to eachother. It almost makes the game feel like an autoscroller at some points. Many of the level's designs are completely uninspired, they're basically rehashed from the first 2 Sonic Games.

- Splash Hill Zone is your average Green Hill Zone-ish level. This Stage's boss is based off of Green Hill's.
- Casino Street Zone is basically Casino Night Zone. It almost feels like a carbon copy of the zone from Sonic 2 at some points. Again, this Stage's boss is based off the one seen in Casino Night.
- Lost Labyrinth is a Labyrinth Zone-ish stage. Nothing much to say here, many of the features from Labyrinth Zone are present here. This stage's boss is based off the one featured in Labyrinth Zone. Noticing a pattern?
- Mad Gear is basically what would happen if Scrap Yard Zone and Metropolis Zone had a baby, as it feels like both of their level designs have been combined together. Not that its a bad thing. The boss here is based off of Metropolis' boss.
- E.G.G Station is the final stage in the game. It consists of a boss gauntlet, and then the big bad, recycled straight from Sonic 2. The final boss is Sonic 2's final boss.

The only thing that makes these bosses different, is that after the fourth hit, they turn into a more powerful version of the original boss. For example, Splash Hill's boss starts flinging the ball towards you.

I was rather disapointed to see that there where no new level themes for Sonic 4: Episode 1. Like, come on Sega, you're calling THIS a sequel to Sonic 3 and Knuckles?

I'll give it that this was only Episode 1, but even Sonic 3 had more level content than this, and that game contained only half of what was planned.

- The Graphics -

Now, this complaint only applies to the PC version. (No, this isn't about Sega not choosing Sonic's classic design).

Sonic's model looks way too shiny. I think this issue is a PC exclusive one though, I don't remember it being as shiny when I played the WiiWare release, though I'll have to check that later.

- The Music -

Pretty mediocre, especially the soundfont. I know this has been said to death before, but it sounds like a bunch of cats.

None of the melodies really stuck to me, it just felt way too generic and unoriginal.



- Stuff I can get behind -

That aside, just because most of the content in this game is unoriginal, or has been used in previous games doesn't mean this game isn't fun to play.

If you don't consider it a sequel to Sonic 3 and Knuckles, its a decent (modern) Sonic game by itself. While the physics don't match those of the genesis games, they're by no means bad.

While the level design can get tedious at times, it's still enjoyable. Not the best, but it could be worse.  It could be Bubsy

If you just want a game to play casually, or are just bored, then Sonic 4: Episode 1 is probably a good choice. Otherwise, just play something else.

If you want to pretend this game never happended, Sonic Retro has tons of rom hacks and fan games that could easily be considered better then this, so check that site out if you want to.

reviewText:
Sonic the Hedgehog, who doesn't know of him by now? A Sega character who started off on the Sega Mega Drive / Genesis, this guy has been in games for over 20 years, rescuing small animals from the evil Doctor Robotnik. The original trilogy were a great bunch of games, and still makes Sega plenty of cash through numerous collections, but not all of the games released since then have been so popular, with several considered to be truly bad. More recently, the series has been returning to quality games with Generations and Colors.

Story
This game strips away a lot of the clutter that the series has added over the years. Once again, it is just Sonic, Robotnik and a hoard of Badniks (the robots that contain many of the captive animals). Once again Robotnik is causing trouble, and Sonic aims to stop him from taking over.

Presentation
The graphics in this game obviously want to get you right in the nostalgia. You will see a lot of stuff you remember from the classic games, only now in a much higher resolution. Level style, enemies, special levels, all are little more than updated versions of classic content. I won't deny that it looks pretty, but it would have been nice to see some more new content during the levels rather than rehashed tiles. A problem I did have was some flickering occurring on the background objects.

Sound wise, this starts off with the classic SEGA! intro jingle which I'm sure many fans will remember. And from there, it goes onto mostly forgettable tunes, though some updated classics exist in the soundtrack. The sound effects stick to the classics as well, with everything in the levels making the sounds you would expect.

Controls
Playing with an XBox 360 controller, I have to say these work well enough. You move with the left analog stick and jump with the A or B button. Later on, you can transform to Super Sonic, which is mapped to the Y button. Other than pausing the game with Start, nothing more is required to play this game. It also has acceptable controls for keyboard, using the arrow keys and Space bar.

Gameplay
Each Zone is remixed from classic levels, with most of them sure to be familiar to long time players of the series. You have Splash Hill in the style of classic Green Hill levels, Casino Street which takes Casino and spring based levels, Lost Labyrinth with the expected ruins and water, and Mad Gear which brings back the mechanical base levels. There is also E.G.G. Station, which consists of a boss run and final boss fight in Robotnik's typical space base, and the Special Stage, which is the seven levels containing the Chaos Emeralds, and based on the special levels from the original game.

Each of the 4 main Zones has 4 Acts with the final Act always having a boss fight against Robotnik. Most of these fights have been taken from previous games, but since each fight is split into two sections where Robotnik tries new tactics, at least you won't be expecting everything.

Despite each Zone having a main theme, most Acts will each have a gimmick to set them apart from other levels in the game. One level will have you running through dark ruins with a burning torch to light your way, another will have you shooting yourself from cannons, a third will have you escaping from a giant cog. This will keep the levels from being too repetitive despite many of the gimmicks being featured in older games.

Lifespan
Beyond the main levels of the game you still have the seven Chaos Emeralds to collect, with all seven unlocking Super Sonic as a playable character, as fans would expect. Within this game, he is playable in the regular levels, a feature that hasn't been part of the series since the original Mega Drive games, with other titles giving him his own special level to complete at the end of the game. There is also a total of 12 achievements to unlock during the game if you are interested in such things.

While this game might not be to the same standard as the classic trilogy, it is still a decent game for the series, and worth playing through if you enjoy the Sonic games.

They actually did Sonic some justice in this game. It doesn’t suck like most of the more recent games (looking at you Sonic Boom: Rise of Lyric, Black Knight, and Secret Rings >_>), but it doesn’t copy everything from the past Sonic games. It copies a little, with the side scrolling and level theme borrowing. Then they spiced up his classic look and gave him the homing attack which is the best thing they could have done for the 2D Sonic series. Although the game is great, it does have its flaws. One of these flaws is very tight controls. Sonic games usually do have tighter controls of most games but thats because of the speed aspect. But no. in this game you stop on a DIME. This is super annoying and makes you overshoot or undershoot your position. Also the jumping is hit or miss. You move to the exact location of where you moved and stop. It can be good for tricky platforming but other times you just won’t move. Don’t know if this is a legit problem or if it’s because I’m playing with a keyboard on PC but whatever. The level design is amazing. They are fast paced fun and have enough difficulty to make them challenging. The four main areas are Splash Hill, Casino Night, Labyrinth, and Scrap Brain (not actual names except Splash Hill). The bosses are even better. They put a spin on the classic Sonic bosses that the zones were based off of. The controls are a little weird but again, I’m using a keyboard. The last thing besides the story that I am going to talk about is the music and it is definitely is Sonic quality music. It sets the scene and provides an upbeat fast paced tone that matches the level so well. Some of my favorite tracks are from the new Casino Night Zone and the new Labyrinth Zone. The last thing left is the story. This is literally “Oh no! Eggman stole the animals! Time to go save them and keep Eggman from destroying the world.” A modern touch on a classic formula that is sure to please any Sonic fan. I can't wait to buy the second episode.\n\nOverall I give this game a 7.5/10

Despite having seen that this game got mixed reviews and even reading the negative ones, my better judgement was nowhere to be found when I bought this game. While it is an updated release that is affably in continuance of the original Genesis series, it lacks the same gameplay. A metric tonne fat kid running from broccoli would be faster than Sonic is in this game. Scratch that, here's a better remark- I could get a 2CV to speed faster than Sonic!

In its defence, however, the levels are non-linear, many of the old sounds have been tweaked a bit for higher fidelity and, the in-level baddies actually serve as decent trip-ups as you lumber down the hills like the Giant Boulder of Death.

I like what they tried to achieve but, they would've been better off making it more like the races from Sonic Adventure 2.

This game had a LOT of potential when it was announced, and I was even excited to try it after I tried the demo. Of course, though, at this time, the Sonic series wasn't doing too hot. I hate to say it, especially since I grew up with the older Sonic games and liked all of them, but Sonic 4 Episode 1 reminds me of why I should look more beyond the demo.

+++Pros+++
The only things I can really talk about have catches to them, and that is that Sega cares about their audience and listens to them (the old Genesis games being the prime of Sonic's existence) and this game tries to honor that, and as well, there's a lot of throwback to Sonic 1 & a little bit of Sonic 2.

---Cons---
-Annoying physics. This is the huge game-breaker for me, and why most of the game isn't as good as it could be. I don't like Sonic immediately stopping on a hill, and when I morph into a ball and roll down the hill, I don't really feel a nice pick up in speed. It's also quite obvious sometimes when you get hit and lose your rings. Sometimes they'll fall right in front of you and you can pick them up, while other times they fly off and frustrate you as you try to hold on to one ring.

-Stupid collision detection. It may not be obvious in the first couple of zones in the game, but in the second half you'll notice it more, especially in the labyrinth zone. You will get hit from a distance and sometimes your attacks on the bosses don't do anything.

-The final boss's execution is horrendous. I didn't like having to be forced to fight the first four forms of Eggman before going to the finale. They could've cut that out and made a Boss rush" mode out of that. I also hated how it was just a massive endurance fight (you have to hit him like 30 times before you finally beat the game)

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1 isn't a bad game, but it definitely could have been better. For something made to be a sequel to Sonic 3 and Knuckles (or just Sonic the Hedgehog 3, but they were meant to be one game), it really doesn't feel similar. This is the first Sonic game as far as I know to have NO MOVEMENT AFTER YOU LET GO OF A DIRECTION. The caps might have been unnecessary, sure, but seriously, the fact that Sonic keeps moving after you let go of the button has always been a big part of the controls. Without that, it almost doesn't even feel like a Sonic game. It takes getting used to. As of the time I'm writing this I've finished the game with 4 chaos emeralds and it still feels totally wrong to me.

I mentioned the chaos emeralds already, so I'll explain that now. The emeralds are in special stages, which you get to the same way you did in Sonic the Hedgehog. If you have 50 rings or more when you get to the end of a level, a giant floating ring will appear. If you're quick, you can jump in and go to a special stage. The special stages are like the ones in the original as well, except you control the whole level instead of Sonic. You have to rotate the level and let the weird physics do the rest. They're hard, though. Maybe not the first one, but after that they get very challenging, each in its own way. This would be fine if you could unlock each one to play later if you fail, but you have to go all the way through a level where you haven't already got an emerald before you can get another chance. It's stupid, it's frustrating, and it wastes your time. If it was done well, I would totally say the special stage is good replay value, but unfortunately it just isn't this time.

The music is good and a lot of the sound effects from the Genesis games are reused, for those who care. The graphics look a bit odd--maybe even sloppy, if you don't mind my boldness--but they're not bad and they work. The level design isn't very good in the beginning, and that comes back near the end. A lot of themes from Sonic 1 and 2 were reused here, which is a nice touch for people who played those.

I don't like this nearly as much as the Genesis games and Sonic CD, but it's still decent and I'm looking forward to playing more of Episode 2 (right now I've done the first level and finished Episode Metal). To be honest, I'm slightly relieved to be finished with this game. I have three emeralds left, and I'll go back for them eventually, but for now I think I'll move on to something else.

A terrible game. I like Sonic, but I can say that this is a terrible game. Awful graphics, unfair bosses, terrible level design, unfair deaths, lame music, especially for a Sonic game. Definitely not worth 10 dollars.

The spin dash as a form of acceleration is useless, it doesn't even get you to max speed. Using the homing attack, instead, gets you at max speed in less than a second without having to charge it. However, using the homing attack as an attack is useless and is often the slowest option to move across an enemy laden screen. The homing attack is also a burden to use when the reticle decides to not track an enemy as long as it occasionally does.

The physics, oh god... They're terrible and unintuitive and inconsistent. It feels like you're walking through six inches of mud, and you stumble into corners of ledges. Sometimes you don't stay in a ball long enough in the air, which proves problematic when anything aerial is hard to control in the first place and there are enemies you almost hit, but have hit you instead. Sometimes you walk up the wall 30 feet, backwards, with no input, and sometimes you struggle to hop up a small incline. Suffice to say, precision is not this game's strong suit.

There are miscellaneous strange choices involved in this game's creation, too. Why do acts' title screens look like the Chilean flag? Why does the mouse cursor stay visible in fullscreen mode when there are no mouse controls? Why are pictures of required inputs on menus not replaced with whatever you're really supposed to press, as opposed to the colored rectangles that represent whatever controller's buttons this game originally played with? How does a 2D game have camera issues?

When you go into the game, go in without expectations and above all, don't keep trying to compare it to the previous three.  Especially in terms of the physics and control. As long as you stick to this, you'll find a fairly enjoyable game. It's pretty good, but not truly the real Sonic 4 it could have been. The reasons for this notably boils down to three issues in particular: Use nostalgia, progression, and level design.

First off is the appeal of nostalgia, it was unfortunately far too heavily use. With too much borrowing from previous games with the Sonic 1 style bonus stages, and nearly every boss being a rehash with minor tweaks at critical health. The level themes were all very close too in style to previous games, which made it felt more of a reimaging than a sequel.

Hand in hand with the nostalgia overload, the game was extremely conservative in the progression department. The bosses as mentioned above were a certainly a major notable case. However, lots of finer details are also affected by this as well. Gone are items introduced in Sonic 2 and 3, leaving only basic ones introduced in Sonic 1… namely just Shields, Power Sneakers, Ring and 1-Up monitors. Although not exactly bad simplifying things to focus on gameplay, it definitely is odd to have the first three progress in complexity and item count to have it go back to square one…
Alongside this, the game doesn’t really introduce anything new to the series to give it that “Sonic 4” feel. The only new aspect added was the homing attack, which certainly met with mixed reactions. Though it does at least give it that new feel and gives it a progression between the classic series and the modern series putting in the homing attack.

Finally, the level design in the game is often quite questionable at parts. The first level is fantastic, along with the third… but just about every level after these two has quirks with them. Often you’ll find horribly booby trapped, cheap tricks, or heavily gimmicked sections RIGHT before the signpost… which means if you need rings for the bonus stage you can pretty much forget it unless you have the level memorized like the back of your hand. Now that’s not bad to put a challenge for the player right before the exit… but there are good ways to do it and then there are bad ways to do it.
And if the traps before the signpost weren’t enough to keep your mind busy, you’ll likely have noticed how many times you came across cheaply placed enemies that offer not a challenge, but instead only frustration. Jumping on a spring or running through a speed booster shouldn’t result in an immediate collision with an enemy for instance.
Then we have Mad Gear 3…  certainly an experience.

However despite these shortcomings, I still find myself coming back to the game from time to time. It’s enjoyable, and is simple fun like a classic game should be. It has enjoyable graphics (though the shading is a bit of an unusual choice for the characters compared to the scenery), is challenging, and is a lot of fun to be Super Sonic again in a game instead of it being a story element. It may take a little to get used to it initially, but definitely worth a look into if you want a classic game experience.

For those who are interested i am about to list reasons for this but for those who arent i will just say that it is a reasonable 2D sonic game but it certainly is not worthy of being called sonic the hedgehog 4. It was fun to play up until the last boss which i have been attempting to beat for the past ten minutes or so at the time of writing and still have not managed it. it is a nice nostalgia trip but not a great game in itself merely an ok sonic game and it really varys from peson to person as to whever or not it is what they are looking for.

Now for details
Positives

. It serves well as a nostalgia trip so for those who are looking for that kind of thing then yes this game has it in spades.

. Fun gameplay for what it is, it is nothing like the old games at all but it is not terrible and yes despite thinking that the game is not worthy to be called Sonic the Hedgehog 4, i still think it is fun

. Super Sonic is available in normal stages and the chaos emeralds can be collected from special stages which i always like to see. Collecting the Emeralds used to be the only reason i played sonic games when i was younger so i shall not complain about that.

Negatives

. The games physics are certainly not like past sonic games and it is most notable in the games speed. by this I mean that there is none, unless you hit a speed boost. this makes the game feel very artificial as whenever you start to move fast you know it is not because of your own actions (i.e. rolling into a ball on a slope like in sonics 1-3) some people may have no problem with this but having played this straight after the classic games it was a notable difference.

. The presentation of the game overall may look nice enough but it certainly has flaws. an example of this could be sonics animations, his slowest running speed is walking pace which makes the game feel incredibly slow as it takes so long for sonic to actually start to run. Also the music is forgettable except for tunes like the supersonic tune and boss battle music as they are so short and on a constant loop that the notes are carved into your very soul.

. There are so many nods to the past games that it really doesnt feel like it is even its own game, all stages are not inspired by previous games but actually feel like they have been taken from previous games and given a makeover, there really is not an original stage in the whole game (original gameplay ideas and puzzles yes but not a lot). this is the same for boss battles as well as they really are just taken from previous games and given new attacks to fight you with. Really not original in the slightest

. Final Point, This is a small nitpick of mine but i feel it is worth noting. the description claims that this game continues the story of the classic games, this really is not true. while the classics where light on story sonic 3 and sonic and knuckles has small scenes scattered throughout the game to give the player and idea of what is happening (like eggman betraying knuckles for the master emerald and knuckles then proceeding to help you) this game has none of that and as a result has no story. so how does it continue from the classic games if it gives the player no idea as to what is actually happening? like i said more of a nitpick but worth noting.

So my final thoughts are that if it is a nostalgia trip you are looking for or just a short and fun sonic game then yes pick it up. however if you are looking for Sonic the Hedgehog 4" this is not it

When you go into the game, go in without expectations and above all, don't keep trying to compare it to the previous three.  Especially in terms of the physics and control. As long as you stick to this, you'll find a fairly enjoyable game. It's pretty good, but not truly the real Sonic 4 it could have been. The reasons for this notably boils down to three issues in particular: Use nostalgia, progression, and level design.

First off is the appeal of nostalgia, it was unfortunately far too heavily use. With too much borrowing from previous games with the Sonic 1 style bonus stages, and nearly every boss being a rehash with minor tweaks at critical health. The level themes were all very close too in style to previous games, which made it felt more of a reimaging than a sequel.

Hand in hand with the nostalgia overload, the game was extremely conservative in the progression department. The bosses as mentioned above were a certainly a major notable case. However, lots of finer details are also affected by this as well. Gone are items introduced in Sonic 2 and 3, leaving only basic ones introduced in Sonic 1… namely just Shields, Power Sneakers, Ring and 1-Up monitors. Although not exactly bad simplifying things to focus on gameplay, it definitely is odd to have the first three progress in complexity and item count to have it go back to square one…
Alongside this, the game doesn’t really introduce anything new to the series to give it that “Sonic 4” feel. The only new aspect added was the homing attack, which certainly met with mixed reactions. Though it does at least give it that new feel and gives it a progression between the classic series and the modern series putting in the homing attack.

Finally, the level design in the game is often quite questionable at parts. The first level is fantastic, along with the third… but just about every level after these two has quirks with them. Often you’ll find horribly booby trapped, cheap tricks, or heavily gimmicked sections RIGHT before the signpost… which means if you need rings for the bonus stage you can pretty much forget it unless you have the level memorized like the back of your hand. Now that’s not bad to put a challenge for the player right before the exit… but there are good ways to do it and then there are bad ways to do it.
And if the traps before the signpost weren’t enough to keep your mind busy, you’ll likely have noticed how many times you came across cheaply placed enemies that offer not a challenge, but instead only frustration. Jumping on a spring or running through a speed booster shouldn’t result in an immediate collision with an enemy for instance.
Then we have Mad Gear 3…  certainly an experience.

However despite these shortcomings, I still find myself coming back to the game from time to time. It’s enjoyable, and is simple fun like a classic game should be. It has enjoyable graphics (though the shading is a bit of an unusual choice for the characters compared to the scenery), is challenging, and is a lot of fun to be Super Sonic again in a game instead of it being a story element. It may take a little to get used to it initially, but definitely worth a look into if you want a classic game experience.

In a desperate attempt to return Sonic to his glory days, Sonic Team gives us Sonic 4: Episode 1. For the most part, the group does a good job of recapturing the feel of the older games. However, the game suffers from awful and nonsensical physics, as well as stiff, wonky controls even on a gamepad. The music is surprisingly forgettable, save for a few tracks. The level design is unique and expansive, though there are quite a few unfair traps and obstacles, especially in the later levels.

If you're just doing a regular playthrough of this game, you won't have too much of an issue with the awful physics and controls, and you'll even have a good time with the open-ended levels and unique art style. If you're trying to 100-percent this game...well, you might want to start taking anger-management classes. Recommended for normal playing, NOT recommended for anything other than one and done.

Note: I forgot to mention the homing dash. Gives you a nice little distance, even if the targeting is quirky. It's the one addition to the Sonic formula that I would love to see revisited and expanded upon, as it really helps you regain control of Sonic's momentum. Maybe in Episode 2???

Game: Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 83/100
Value Score: 8.3/10

• Story: 7/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1 takes place shortly after the events of Sonic 3 & Knuckles and sometime before the events of any other Sonic game. Sonic has decided to part with Tails and go on a new adventure himself in a new land. In the meantime Dr. Eggman has decided to take out Sonic after enhancing his machines.

• Characters: 7/10
o Sonic and Dr. Eggman return in the game however there arent any new characters or any other returning characters however the enemies have changed dramatically from what they've been in other games and offers a fresh new look and feel to the sonic series.

• GamePlay: 9/10
o Just like any other Sonic game, you go through different zones with different acts and a boss battle at the end. A lot of the familiar features and abilities from past Sonic games have been re-introduced along with the fact that Sonic can now use the homing attack (which was a unique skill in the Adventure series) in the game. The gameplay has a bit more puzzle aspects compared to the other 2D games. Just like any other sonic game you have check point posts where if you die you can come back to rather than starting all over again - you will also be able to collect chaos emeralds to eventually become Super Sonic to reach new heights like the other games.

• Graphics: 10/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 uses a new engine for its visual design. Completely going off the usual 2D 16 bit retro area style - the developers decided to rework the original engine in modern light. The game's far more fluid in motion than any sonic game that has been out. The visual designs are nicely done with everything from the appearance, lighting to the texture. Absolutely one of the most gorgeous looking games to be made with a appealing and colorful tone.

• Sound: 10/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 uses a reworked audio/sound system which brings back a lot of the old tunes from the older games but remakes them with a better bitrate and quality.

• Music: 9/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 uses completely new sound track and offers little to no remixes from the older games (most of which are just the usual themes you would expect such as clearing a act). Despite that fact it still has and uses similar style to the old industrial tech tunes we are so familiar with the older sonic games.

• Length: 5/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1's main fault is the length. Although there are 5 zones with 3 acts each - you can easily finish the game within 2-3 hours. Of course there is time attack to make your records better but that isnt really appealing.

• Replay Value: 7/10
o Despite the fact that the length of the game isnt as much - the level designs are nicely done and offer different paths like the older games. You also have the option to play the special stages again which you have completed. You also have the option to directly fight a boss of a zone rather than going through a set of acts before having a chance to fight them.

• Player Value: 9/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode is an amazing sequel with what they've done adding a Sonic in a colorful and vivid world, amazing fluid visuals, a upbeat Soundtrack, and amazing re-telling of Sonic's fight against Dr. Eggman. However despite that it still has its faults such as the fact that the game's length is a bit of a lowside and the lack of some key Sonic characters missing out. Regardless this game is still a nice addition to the hardcore Sonic fan and any fan of the platformer/adventure genre.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1 isn't a bad game, but it definitely could have been better. For something made to be a sequel to Sonic 3 and Knuckles (or just Sonic the Hedgehog 3, but they were meant to be one game), it really doesn't feel similar. This is the first Sonic game as far as I know to have NO MOVEMENT AFTER YOU LET GO OF A DIRECTION. The caps might have been unnecessary, sure, but seriously, the fact that Sonic keeps moving after you let go of the button has always been a big part of the controls. Without that, it almost doesn't even feel like a Sonic game. It takes getting used to. As of the time I'm writing this I've finished the game with 4 chaos emeralds and it still feels totally wrong to me.

I mentioned the chaos emeralds already, so I'll explain that now. The emeralds are in special stages, which you get to the same way you did in Sonic the Hedgehog. If you have 50 rings or more when you get to the end of a level, a giant floating ring will appear. If you're quick, you can jump in and go to a special stage. The special stages are like the ones in the original as well, except you control the whole level instead of Sonic. You have to rotate the level and let the weird physics do the rest. They're hard, though. Maybe not the first one, but after that they get very challenging, each in its own way. This would be fine if you could unlock each one to play later if you fail, but you have to go all the way through a level where you haven't already got an emerald before you can get another chance. It's stupid, it's frustrating, and it wastes your time. If it was done well, I would totally say the special stage is good replay value, but unfortunately it just isn't this time.

The music is good and a lot of the sound effects from the Genesis games are reused, for those who care. The graphics look a bit odd--maybe even sloppy, if you don't mind my boldness--but they're not bad and they work. The level design isn't very good in the beginning, and that comes back near the end. A lot of themes from Sonic 1 and 2 were reused here, which is a nice touch for people who played those.

I don't like this nearly as much as the Genesis games and Sonic CD, but it's still decent and I'm looking forward to playing more of Episode 2 (right now I've done the first level and finished Episode Metal). To be honest, I'm slightly relieved to be finished with this game. I have three emeralds left, and I'll go back for them eventually, but for now I think I'll move on to something else.

In my opinion, a lot of Sonic games are better in 2D. I still enjoy 3D, but most of the time they are just too boxed up, with not enough room to move. 2D levels, however, offer more paths to be placed in a smaller area, allowing exploration to become a bigger component in this game.

Final Verdict:

A great little case of faint nostalgia at a relatively cheap price. Definitely worth the money!

When you go into the game, go in without expectations and above all, don't keep trying to compare it to the previous three.  Especially in terms of the physics and control. As long as you stick to this, you'll find a fairly enjoyable game. It's pretty good, but not truly the real Sonic 4 it could have been. The reasons for this notably boils down to three issues in particular: Use nostalgia, progression, and level design.

First off is the appeal of nostalgia, it was unfortunately far too heavily use. With too much borrowing from previous games with the Sonic 1 style bonus stages, and nearly every boss being a rehash with minor tweaks at critical health. The level themes were all very close too in style to previous games, which made it felt more of a reimaging than a sequel.

Hand in hand with the nostalgia overload, the game was extremely conservative in the progression department. The bosses as mentioned above were a certainly a major notable case. However, lots of finer details are also affected by this as well. Gone are items introduced in Sonic 2 and 3, leaving only basic ones introduced in Sonic 1… namely just Shields, Power Sneakers, Ring and 1-Up monitors. Although not exactly bad simplifying things to focus on gameplay, it definitely is odd to have the first three progress in complexity and item count to have it go back to square one…
Alongside this, the game doesn’t really introduce anything new to the series to give it that “Sonic 4” feel. The only new aspect added was the homing attack, which certainly met with mixed reactions. Though it does at least give it that new feel and gives it a progression between the classic series and the modern series putting in the homing attack.

Finally, the level design in the game is often quite questionable at parts. The first level is fantastic, along with the third… but just about every level after these two has quirks with them. Often you’ll find horribly booby trapped, cheap tricks, or heavily gimmicked sections RIGHT before the signpost… which means if you need rings for the bonus stage you can pretty much forget it unless you have the level memorized like the back of your hand. Now that’s not bad to put a challenge for the player right before the exit… but there are good ways to do it and then there are bad ways to do it.
And if the traps before the signpost weren’t enough to keep your mind busy, you’ll likely have noticed how many times you came across cheaply placed enemies that offer not a challenge, but instead only frustration. Jumping on a spring or running through a speed booster shouldn’t result in an immediate collision with an enemy for instance.
Then we have Mad Gear 3…  certainly an experience.

However despite these shortcomings, I still find myself coming back to the game from time to time. It’s enjoyable, and is simple fun like a classic game should be. It has enjoyable graphics (though the shading is a bit of an unusual choice for the characters compared to the scenery), is challenging, and is a lot of fun to be Super Sonic again in a game instead of it being a story element. It may take a little to get used to it initially, but definitely worth a look into if you want a classic game experience.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 1 is a game that had its work cut out for it,
and sadly, it falls a bit short.
The game, rather than expanding on the ideas of Sonic 3 & K's
multiple characters, shields and storyline integration,
is visually a rehash of the zones, bells and whistles of Sonic 1 and 2.
That's not to say the game doesn't do original ideas,
in fact, every act is flavored with an unique gimmick of one sort or another,
and it actually generally work really well.
The control on the other hand, imagine Sonic Rush, Colors or Generations' modern stages.
Now take away the boost and what you're left with is one rather clunky Sonic.
This game is perhaps the worst example of Dimps' level design as well,
with bubble-chains, speed-boosters and bottomless pits looming below the end of several acts
as if it somehow constitutes for challenge, made even more frustrating knowing that contrary to popular beliefs, Dimps can make great Sonic games.
Still, the game is a fairly decent little romp,
but I can't with a good conscience recommend this
when there are so many great alternatives readily available on Steam.

So sonic has now gone back to his 2D roots in this game as he speeds through NOT-Green Hill Zone (Splash Hill Zone), NOT-Casino Night Zone (Casino Street Zone), NOT-Labyrinth Zone (Lost Labyrinth Zone) and NOT- Scrap Brain/Metropolis Zone (Mad Gear Zone). While the level themes my be reused the level design is all original like Splash Hill has vines to swing on, Casino street has card and cannons, Lost Labyrinth has minecart and the wonderful torch puzzle and Mad Gear has gears, gears and more gears... The Bosses are all previous creations like the swing ball eggman and the... Death egg Robot that by the way takes place in NOT-Death Egg Zone (E.G.G Station Zone). Well Sonic himself sports his modern design and can still jump on enemies, do nthe spin dash and do the homing at.. wait sonic doesn't homing attack in the classics. Another thing that bothers me is that sonic just feels weightless at times. With just a little speed you can scale up a cliff no problem at all and when t=you let go off the d-pad sonic stops almost dead in his tracks like hes got magnets on the bottom of his shoes. thats not how it should be! When I was younger I was a sonic fan and I own all Genesis/Megadrive, Mastersystem and Dreamcast Sonic games even today. My favorite game was Sonic 3 & Knuckles but sadly Sonic 4 is a HUGE disappointment.

The physics and controls are not the same as the previous games, they try to behave the same but they kinda... feel fake.

Level design isn't that great either, in fact it tries to imitate most design and content from the previous titles, including the boss fights, where's the originality in that? Each title always had something new and fresh.

Length of the game it's too short, yeah I know it's just 1 of 2 episodes, but that strategy was just to cash in on the same game twice.

Overall, this game wasn't clearly designed by the original team behind the previous games (I should appreciate more info about this).

In resume:

PROS:
* Well... Sonic?
* Nice 3D visuals
* 2D Gameplay
* No cutscenes
* No new characters to fill yet more the Sonic universe.

CONS:
* Fake physics & controls regarding the previous titles.
* Nothing significantly new in gameplay.
* References of old games takes 95% of the game, I might as well play the old ones then...
* Too short, only 5+Special Zones, Sonic 2 has 11+Special.

If you want a modern sonic game that is good go get Sonic Generations instead.
